text: I step forward, keeping my voice as gentle as possible.
“Friends, the drinks are on me. No need to get angry.”
The drunk glares furiously and shoves me aside. Wine spills across the floor as his fist slams onto the counter, the wood letting out a dull crack.
“Stop pretending to be a good person!”
“Everyone in this town looks down on me, don’t they?!”
I’m forced back step by step, several cups falling from the shelves and shattering, the sound piercingly loud in the silent tavern.
His eyes are muddled and wild, fury burning in them like a trapped beast as he advances.
I raise my hands, about to speak again, when the wind outside suddenly intensifies and the door slams with a loud bang.
The hearth fire is pressed low by the wind, flames flickering violently in the air. Everyone holds their breath.
Cold air from the doorway surges in with the light, carrying the chill of snow and the scent of metal.
The cloaked woman’s gaze falls upon the drunk—calm, yet sharper than the winter wind.
“Looks like I arrived just in time. Are mornings here always this noisy?”
Her voice is clear, without menace, yet it naturally brings silence to the room.
The drunk opens his mouth to curse, but it is as if some invisible force grips his throat. The air grows still.
My heart tightens. The fire flares back to life, light and shadow dancing as her silver hair gleams in the glow like the reflection of a blade.
She lifts a finger and flicks it lightly. The bottle spins gently in her palm, the spilled wine turning into a fine mist that sparkles in the firelight.
Everything falls silent. Even the drunk himself freezes, as if his anger has been suddenly drawn away.
Only then do I realize the entire tavern’s air has come to a standstill—even the flames no longer waver.
“That’s enough.”
The drunk’s throat bobs, his lips trembling a few times, yet no words come out. He steps back, nearly slipping.
“Damn it… crazy woman…”
Panting, he mutters curses under his breath, then shoves the door open and staggers into the snowstorm.
The door slams shut behind him, snow swirling in the wind. The tavern returns to silence.
I take a deep breath, my chest still burning. Her gaze brushes over me lightly; there is no reproach in her eyes, only a faint trace of tenderness.
I open my mouth, but no words come. The fire resumes its dance, its light reflecting in her eyes like a bottomless lake of snow.
